prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(4-3) high resolution
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
SG 1: Measure the CO(4-3) morphology and kinematics at 0.1" resolution.
Configuration C36-7, can be observed at night time in November 2015.
We will use these observations to quantify the Schmidt-Kennicutt law down to about 35 pc in the source plane and to measure the velocity offsets and line widths of individual clumps. This will provide the constraints needed for the gas velocities, dynamical times, and gas mass surface densities in part (A), the velocity offsets and FWHM needed for the feedback in part (B), and the line fluxes needed for the diagnostics of part (C) of the scientific justification.
We also cover HNC(5-4) as bonus with one baseband, which may be interesting to complement the HNC(5-4) measurements in SG 2. In addition, we will cover the continuum with two more basebands as an additional bonus observation. The main science driver of this SG is the CO(4-3), which determines the configuration and setups of this SGs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We wish to probe the line widths and velocity gradients, and therefore need to resolve the line with at least a few resolution elements. The total bandwidth per spectral window is largely sufficient to cover the full expected dynamic range of the velocities and widths. We prefer an intrinsic resolution of 2.5 rather than ~90 km/s in this case, because we might find individual, narrow, bright components superimposed on more turbulent gas, which we should be able to resolve in high-surface brightness regions. The band width will not be affected by this.

Our angular resolution is chosen such that we resolve scales < 100 pc in the source plane. This is a scientific choise, because at around 100 pc size, the large-scale rotational support no longer dominates, so we can truly resolve the processes within individual star-forming regions. At 0.1" scales (as opposed to 0.03") we also find an acceptable, LAS, although our main science goal are the high-resolution clumps, not the putative diffuse, more extended emission.

The sensitivity estimate is solely based on the expected surface brightness of CO(4-3), other subbands are just bonus. We already know the dust morphology at 850um (observed) at 0.3" resolution from our SMA map, and will assume constant CO(4-3)/dust ratios. Our main interest is to cover and resolve the bright clumps, since we are mainly interested in the upper limit of intense star formation. We find that we need about 15 apertures of 0.1" each to cover these blobs, which will be unresolved in the direction perpendicular to the lensing axis (see, e.g., Vlahakis et al. 2007 for the example of the lens SDP.81).
The integrated peak line flux density is 39 mJy from our IRAM/30-m EMIR spectrum. This means we need to probe on average about 2 mJy per beam at 0.1" resolution. With the requested rms=0.2 mJy this correponds to SNR=10. According to the sensitivity calculator this can be reached in about 1 hr on-source, 2 hrs of total observations split into two blocks.
We also verified with the ALMA simulator that a beam of approximately 0.1"x0.1" can indeed be achieved with this single configuration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dense gas tracers (5-4)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
SG (2): Dense gas tracers -- HCO+, HCN, HNC J=5-4, 13CO4-3
Configuration C36-5, can be observed in May/June 2016 during night time. We aim at isolating individual clumps seen in the 0.5" beam SMA map in Fig. 1 of the science justification.
Goal of this SG is to provide the line fluxes of HCO+, HCN, HNC (all are J=5-4 transitions) and 13CO4-3. We will use the line ratios to probe the gas excitation, and in particular the 13CO4-3/12CO4-3 ratio, to constrain the column densities, one of the most important parameters to break degeneracies between density and mechanical heating in our line diagnostics.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: If the dense gas tracers probe dense star-forming cores, and if turbulence has been effectively dissipated away at larger scales, then it is possible that these lines will be much more narrow than the CO lines. This could be hinted at by the faint line profiles of the HCO+ and HCN line detected with IRAM/EMIR on the 30m telescope at SNR~3. A reference value of 150 km/s seems appropriate for that, and would probably provide integrated line fluxes. Note that our intrisic resolution for all lines is motivated by our need to cover 4 lines with 1/4 of the total bandwidth each. This will also give us additional flexibility, e.g., if finding particularly bright lines, we can use more narrow channels to probe the fine details of the line profile, e.g., multiple narrow components.

Our SMA map at 850 um shows that the source is a 1.5" diameter Einstein ring with multiple bright clumps near the caustic line. Our goal is to isolate each clump with a beam of 0.3". This means we expect to find 5 sources. A resolution of 0.3" seems optimal to be nearly beam-filling along the axis streched by the lens. In orthogonal direction, we expect the arc to be very narrow, see, e.g., Vlahakis et al. (2015), the high-resolution observations of the lensed galaxy SDP.81.

As the above summary shows, we target an rms=0.15 mJy, which we can reach with weather in the 2nd quartile in 2 hrs of total observing time with a channel width of 150 km/s.
We base our flux estimates on the faint (3-sigma) detection of HCO+ and HCN with IRAM/EMIR, giving a peak flux density of about 3.5 mJy for the source-integrated lines. Since we expect the lensed source to be very narrow perpendicular to the ring, we dissect the lens into 5 resolution elements a ~0.5" (see Fig. 1 in the science justification), each covering one bright clump. We therefore expect on average between 0.7 and 3.5 mJy of peak flux density, depending on how many clumps contribute to the observed line emission. With an rms of 0.15 mJy, we therefore expect a snr between 5 and 23 per clump. This will be sufficient to perform line diagnostics, and basic line profiles, in particular line widths. Note that our intrinsic spectral resolution will be much higher, so that we can do more detailed analyses of the line profiles for the brightest clumps. Please note also that we tuned the frequency of HCO+ to a suitable representative frequency in the OT. Although the spectral setup allows to observe all lines in one observation, the requirement of the OT that the representative frequency falls into the center of the representative window made it impossible to properly show this in the OT. We were assured by teh ALMA staff that this is not an issue for the actual observing.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Absorption-line probe of the wind in G244.8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Goal is to map OH in this galaxy, which has a an extraordinary continuum brightness, reaching a peak brightness at 1 Jy.
We will use band 9 in the C36-1 configuration, which will allow to observe this SG during night time in May 2016 with a beam of about 0.5".
OH seen in absorption would be an excellent probe of molecular outflows at high-z, which is prohibitively difficult to obtain for almost all other high-z galaxies. This is a unique experiment enabled by this outstanding source.
The spectral setup is identical to that of our approved cycle 2 program. Note that we list the continuum flux as 'line strength' below, since this is appropriate for absorption-line studies (where the SNR depends on the continuum flux density, not that of the line).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use the identical spectral setup to the program that is already in the queue for cycle 2 but has not yet been observed. This setup has previously been approved by the ARC in Grenoble. We chose the coarsest correlator setup, with the goal of maximizing the band width. Absorption lines from winds have several interesting parameters, including the offsets between the line core and the emission line, which gives the average outflow velocity, but also the highest velocities at which gas is seen in absorption, which gives the maximal outflow velocity. To be sure we cover both parameters, we have placed the 4 sub-bands such that they will cover a large continuous spectral range of >2000 km/s covering the maximum expected width of the absorption line and sufficent unabsorbed continuum to reliably identify the maximum outflow velocity. We also allow for overlap between the different sub-bands to ensure a good relative flux calibration between individual sub-bands.

Our SMA map shows that G244.8 is a near-complete Einstein ring with 1.5" diameter, so we will over the source with 4 beams. Assuming that the 630-345 GHz colors are fairly uniform across the source, we expect that most emission will come from the southern part of the ring, which will be unresolved in our data. By isolating the emission from this clump, we might even be able to lower the contamination of the absorption line with emission from other regions of this galaxy, increasing the line depth, and improving the SNR compared to an integrated measurement!

We wish to search for an absorption-line tracer of a wind in a z=3.0 maximum starburst. This program has already been approved and scheduled in cycle 2, but it is currently not clear if it will be observed. If yes, we will give the time back.
We estimate the line flux from the FIR/submm SED constraind by the SPIRE 250, 350, 500 um,SCUBA-2 850 um, and IRAM/GISMO 2mm flux. We also use our existing SMA 850 um image with an 0.3" beam to constrin the dynamir range within this source. G244.8 is a near-complete Einstein ring with 1.5" diameter. We assume uniform colors between 345 GHz and 627 GHz, the frequency at which we wish to observe here. We expect the wind to be launched from the most intensely star-forming regions, in our case the bright knot in the South, which has a size </~0.3" in our SMA map. One beam will cover this blob entirely. If the colors are approximately uniform, then we expect about 400 mJy of flux from this blob alone.
Since we wish to observe an absorption line, we use the continuum flux to estimate the required SNR. As shown above, for 400 mJy of continuum flux, the sensitivity calculator suggests rms = 1.5 mJy, i.e., SNR~270, for 2.09 hrs of total observing time (54.4 min on-source), 1st octile weather, and splitting the program into 2 SBs. This is for a channel width of 250 km/s, sufficient to probe the shape absorption line profile. We also need to take into account, however that the absorption line may only have a finite depth. The value is uncertain. Sturm et al. (2011, ApJ 733, L16) found about 5% in nearby ULIRGs observed in the same line with Herschel, but covered the entire galaxy, in which case their absorption-line signal might have been diluted by emission from other parts of the galaxy. If we reference our SNR estimate to (400mJy*0.05=)20 mJy flux density we find SNR~14. Isolating this clump might however boost the depth of the line profile, so that the Sturm et al. estimate seems very conservative. We are confident that this SNR will be sufficient to measure the depth of the absorption line and its spectral shape.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High-resolution dust morphology
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Our goal is to measure the fine spatial structure of the dust morphology to localize the starburst, measure the sizes of individual star-forming clumps, and their star-formation intensity.
Configuration C36-6. We will observe in band 6, so that observations can also be carried out during daytime.
This SG will enable us to probe the efficiency with which gas is transformed into stars in a maximum starburst on scales of 35-40 pc, assuming a 0.1" beam, and for an average magnification factor of 20. We expect to cover the source with about 15-20 resolution elements along the caustic line, and to have an unresolved source in perpendicular direction.
We used our existing SMA map taken in the extended configuration at 0.3" resolution to estimate the expected surface brightnesses, finding between 4 and 20 mJy/bm. We use these as basis for our exposure time estimate.
The sensitivity calculator suggests that with the aggregate bandwidth of 7 GHz, a representative frequency of 344.3 GHz, in the 7th octile (pwv=0.66 mm), and using two executions, we can reach rms=20 uJy/beam in 4.6 hrs of total execution time (1.65 hrs on-source). For a surface brightness of 4 mJy this corresponds to SNR=200 per 0.3 arcsec beam.
A beam size of approximately 50 mas corresponds to 1/35 of the beam size in our SMA data, so that we expect SNR between 6 and 30 per 0.05 arcsec beam.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our main goal is to probe fine spatial details of the dust, so we use the aggregate bandwidth of 7.5 GHz in band 6. We do cover CO(9-8), and might detect it in the most strongly star-forming apertures, perhaps giant super-star clusters, which would probably have narrow, bright, highlyexcited lines. In this case, we will fit and subtract these lines from the underlying continuum. This is however not the science scope with which we justify our time request, but just a bonus observation.

The main goal of this part of the program is to measure the size of individual star-forming clumps at 100 mas resolution, to match the resolution of CO(4-3) and resolve individual star-forming regions on scales of 35-40 pc. Band 6 is ideal for that.
Note that we had to list LAS=0.7" in the OT to validate the program, but the technical handbook states 2.1" of recoverable scale, which seems more appropriate for a resoution of 0.1". Our main scope in the SG is to probe the gas at the finest resolutions, so that the LAS, provided it is larger than the 0.3" of our SMA maps, is secondary.

We already have a 850 micron map from SMA with a 0.3" resolution of this source, which makes our sensitivity estimates particularly straight-forward. With the spectral slope and the 850 mu morphology, we find surface brightnesses between 2 and 10 mJy per 0.3" beam.
As shown above, the sensitivity calculator suggests that with the aggregate bandwidth of 7 GHz, a we can reach rms=20 uJy/beam in the requested time. For a surface brigthness of 2 mJy this corresponds to SNR=100 per 0.3: arcsec beam. This will be sufficient to resolve each 0.3" beam into several beams of 0.1", even allowing for a dynamic range of factors of a few, as might be expected from the clumpyness seen in SDP.81 (Vlahakis et al. 2015).
We will also cover CO(9-8), and might detect this line if it is bright, narrow, and concentrated, e.g., in individual giant super-star clusters. In this case we will fit and remove it from our cnotinuum measurement. To provide an estimate of the likelihood of a detection, we used the sensitivity calculator with 250 km/s channel width, and find that we can reach rms=200 muJy in half the time requested here. This will allow to probe CO(9-8) from about 25 individual apertures, not impossible for highly concentrated emission, as would be expected if the emission comes from the most intensely star-forming super clusters. Our aim is soleley to identify such concentrated emission.
We also verified with the ALMA simulator that a beam of approximately 0.1"x0.1" can indeed be achieved with this single configuration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Searching the turnover of the CO ladder.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science goal serves mainly science scope (C) in the scientific justification, to identify the turnover of the CO ladder, which would indicate that we probe the main gas comonent in this source, or whether we miss an even more extreme gas component.
Configuration C36.1, source observable at night time.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We chose the coarsest correltor setup which will give us about 30 km/s channels. This will be enough to isolate individual line components while providing good signal-to-noise per bin. We will bin to broader channels to detect fainter emission, if needed. The bandwidth is sufficient to cover the entire line and adjacent continuum.
Our SMA map at 850 um shows that the source is a 1.5" diameter Einstein ring with multiple bright clumps near the caustic line. With an 0.7" beam we will cover the source with at most 4 beams.

We aim at detecting CO(14-13), to search for the turnover in the CO SLED of G244.8 and constrain whether mechanical heating is important or not. We expect to find a similar flux to that of CO(11-10) if it is. We will use the C36-1 configuration (observable at night) to reach 0.7" beam, i.e. cover the source with at most 4 beams. This implies a flux per beam of 6 mJy.
The sensitivity calculator suggests we reach rms=0.8 mJy in 1 hr of total integration. This correponds to SNR=7.5 and will be sufficient. We actually expect most emission to come from the bright clump in the southern part of the ring, which will boost our SNR. A non-detection woul dalso be a meaningful result, suggesting that the extreme excitation would be dominated by density, not mechanical heating.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: ALMA's long baselines now offer a superb chance to probe intense star formation in high-z galaxies on very fine scales of few 10s of pc, if gas and dust surface brightnesses permit. Here we propose to probe the star-formation law and underlying physical mechanisms in the brightest high-z galaxy on the sub-mm sky seen with Planck, a 1.5" diameter Einstein ring with a FIR SED peaking at 1 Jy, and bright CO lines up to at least 11-10. G244.8+54.9 at z=3.0 is a maximal starburst forming ~17900 Ms yr-1 kpc-2, near the Eddington limit, and about 10x more vigorously than the recently observed lensed galaxy SDP.81. We will (1) Characterize gas and star-forming clumps at 30-40 pc resolution (akin to sizes of individual giant molecular clouds!) (2) Search for the peak of the CO ladder and perhaps variations in CO ratios. (3) Probe the kinematics and morphology of the dense gas tracers HCO+, HCN, HNC, and 13CO. Do they really trace a separate component or are they mixed with the CO, perhaps in a turbulent multi-phase environment? (4) Search for feedback and wind signatures, including OH119 in absorption, to break the degeneracy between infall, rotation, turbulence and gas outflow.
